titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. IV:30. Saturday. Bath with Antoine, at five— The tide had about an hour to rise. Mr Bagot called upon me at the Office, and we had conversation upon various subjects— The British Cabinet, and particularly Lord Castlereagh have been much annoyed by the Report of a Committee of the House of Representatives at the last Session of Congress, which remarked that the four Articles proposed by Lord Castlereagh as a
projected addition to the Commercial Convention of 3. July 1815. had been promptly rejected by this Government, although three of them might have been acceptable, because the fourth would have been incompatible with the policy of the United States of excluding foreigners from intercourse with the Indians within our territories— Lord Castlereagh has addressed a note on the subject to Mr Rush, disavowing any such intention, and asking by what course of reasoning the Committee came to their conclusion— We have not yet received a copy of this Note from Rush, but Lord Castlereagh sent one to Mr Bagot, who shewed it to me. I told him that I could not say how the Committee had reasoned; having had no communication with them, other than that of transmitting the papers to them. He then spoke of our Navigation Act of the last Session, which requires that British Vessels laden in our Ports should give Bonds with securities, not to unlade their Cargoes, in any, Port from which Vessels of the United States are excluded. He complained that with regard to British vessels unequivocally engaged only in the direct trade between the British Ports in Europe and the United States, this provision subjected them to a charge, other than those to which the vessels of the United States are subject; and thus was incompatible with the Convention of 3 July 1815. particularly that part which required securities— This was to be strictly considered as an additional charge; which the owners of British vessels trading here, as strangers, could probably not effect, without paying a Commission which is usually charged in such cases— I told him that these Bonds could not be considered as an additional charge— That in bona-fide cases there could be no possible difficulty for the Masters of Vessels to obtain securities; as the most respectable merchants in the Country would very readily give them without charge, for the benefit of the consignment— That in a case bearing much analogy to this; I had addressed his Government, noticing a restriction upon American vessels in England to which British vessels were not subject, as being a charge, within the intent of the Convention of 1815. but his Government did not agree with my reasoning or allow the restriction to be removed— However, if he would address me a Note on the subject, it should receive all proper consideration; and we should readily yield every accommodation compatible with the necessity of carrying our law into effective execution— He spoke also upon the fisheries—and said Lord Castlereagh had written him that orders had again been issued to the Naval Officers on the American station to suspend the captures of American fishing Vessels for the present Season— This measure had been taken, although the British Government had waited Month after Month to receive the proposals which had been so long and so frequently promised here— I told him that the delays which had occurred to the making of those proposals had not been intentional, but occasioned by the varying information which had been received from the parts of the Country most interested in the fisheries, and I added that if Mr Gallatin and Rush to whom I should this day despatch the final instructions for their commercial negotiation should not be able to conclude an article upon this subject, it would be our wish that a final decision by the Lords of Appeal, on the legality of the captures of our fishing vessels should take place, upon a full and solemn argument of all the questions involved in it— I asked him whether Consuls of the United States would be admitted into the free-Ports established by the late Acts of Parliament? He said he did not see that there could be any objection to it, but perhaps the Governors might not feel themselves authorized to admit them. He would however immediately write to ascertain— I sent off to New-York the despatches for Messrs. Gallatin and Rush— Mr Pierce called at the Office, but I had no funds to pay for employing him. Mr Bailey rode home with me from the Office after five O’Clock. Mrs Adams spent the Evening at her sister Boyd’s, who has a child ill. Weather yet oppressively warm—

2. IV:30. Bath alone in the Potowmack—between seven and eight O’Clock— It was the new moon tide and must have been high tide about eight O’Clock. The remainder of the day I passed at home; wasting almost all the time, and flattering myself that it was the heat which disabled me from writing. Neither did I read anything but the Newspapers— The heat continues unremitting.

3. V: Bathed alone again, between seven and eight— It was the Spring tide, 36 hours after the new Moon; the tide was full at eight O’Clock, but not so high as it had been at the last full Moon, the 17th. of last Month— It was One O’Clock, before I went to the Office, and soon after three I was unwell, and obliged to come home, in a Hack, which I met opposite the President’s House. Mr Thomas Barlow was at the Office, for an answer to the questions he had made for additional allowances upon his uncle’s Accounts. Pleasonton had informed me that the accounts had been settled two years ago, at which time the question of these allowances had been made, and they were rejected— A circumstance I had not known when Barlow had applied to me before— I told him now that the account having been once adjusted could not be opened again, without express instructions from the President— I promised to send him Barlow’s statement of the facts and Lee’s Letter supporting it, and to take his directions— Mr R. Forrest who has been some days absent returned this day to the Office.

4. V: Suspended the Morning Baths in the Potowmack; the time of tide not answering for the purpose— Mr ten Cate was at the Office, and I gave him the draft upon the Treasury for his Bills upon his Government. Mr Forsyth was also there and borrowed a statement by Mr Poinsett, which on the files but of which I had no previous knowledge— I came home before four O’Clock. Mrs Adams rode out with Madame de Neuville, Mrs. W. S. Smith and Mary Hellen, where they found only Mr Paulding. I afterwards walked to Madame de Neuville’s, where I found the Ladies, Messrs. ten Cate, Fenwick, Bourqueney and Thierry. There was this Evening a conjunction of Venus Mars and the Moon, which I noticed.

5. VI:30. I endeavour in vain to go at an earlier hour to my Office, and am now again much occupied, and afflicted with the subject of weights and measures. Mr Parry, an Englishman came to the Office— He often came to me when I was in England, with projects of emigrating with his family to this Country; which he has now at length accomplished. He arrived lately at Norfolk, and has come to enquire if he can obtain employment by the Commissioners of the Navy to whom I sent him. I called at Mr Calhoun’s Office with the Certificate sent me by my brother in favour of . . .Oliphant, and to make enquiries concerning the claim of Peter Ellino. Calhoun says there are by estimate already twenty-thousand claims of revolutionary Soldiers, for pensions under the acts of the last Session of Congress— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us and Messrs:ten Cate and Bourqueney spent the Evening here. We had the Piano & singing till near Midnight.

6. VI: Yesterday was nine years from the day of our last departure for Europe, and this day is the anniversary of our landing at New-York on our return. My engagements for the Report concerning weights and measures now absorb most of my time, and I go very late to my Office. Mr Alexander M’Rae, appointed Consul at Amsterdam, and Mr Mitchell late Consul at St. Pierre’s Martinique, and now Candidate for any Office at home came and occupied most of the time while I was at the Office. The heat still oppressive. Mrs Adams spent the Evening abroad— I rode both to and from the Office. Went early to bed, but not to sleep. There was a change to cold weather in the Night.

7. V:45. First day of comfortably cool weather for several weeks. Called at the U.S. Branch Bank, where I met Mr Middleton. Called also at Pleasonton’s Office to ascertain how the advances had been made to Mr Daschkoff in 1810. and Mr Poletica in 1811. for the remittances which were made to me, in order to observe the same form in the advance now to be made to Mr ten Cate— I sent for him and returned his bills to him requesting him to send me others payable to the order of the Bankers of the United States at Amsterdam— ten Cate paid me a long Visit— Mr John Graham and Mr Calhoun were also at the Office. Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us, and her husband came for her after dinner, but she was gone with Mrs. Adams who spent the Evening at her Sister Frye’s—

8. V: Resuming the researches necessary to prepare a Report upon Weights and Measures, I find my time again so absorbed by them that I can make scarce any progress with the Report itself. At the Office I found a Note from Don Manuel H de Aguirre the Agent from Buenos Ayres, asking for
an interview— I sent him a Note appointing three O’Clock for that purpose but it was four when he came, and he was with me an hour. He began by complaining of his having been arrested at New-York by a warrant from Judge Livingston— He said that for some weeks past his house had been a mere house of Marshals and Sheriff’s and Officers of the Law. That he had once been arrested in the Streets, and once taken out of his bed at Midnight by processes at Law, commenced or instigated by the Spanish Consul; though I had told him he might consider himself here as a public Minister— I told him that he had very much mistaken me; that I had very distinctly informed him that he could not be considered here as a Public Minister, for two reasons; one because the Government from which he came was not recognized; and the other because he had produced no credentials or powers as a Public Minister; his Commission, styling him only Agent, and his Letters to the President giving him no authority to negotiate, whatever— That upon both these grounds it was not in the power of the President to exempt or protect him from arrest— That no persons other than Public Ministers and their families were exempted from arrest; not even the President of the United States himself— He then went over the history of his mission to this Country— He was charged to build and despatch to the Government of Chili six Sloops of War, and came to this Country with two hundred thousand dollars in cash and a power to borrow two Millions— He was authorized to pledge the faith of both the Governments of Buenos-Ayres and Chili, for this loan; but the merchants here demanded other security, and said they would be satisfied with the Guaranty of the Government of the United States. He was also authorized to offer a profit of fifty per Cent upon the cost of the vessels to any Merchant who would dispatch them— Upon his arrival here he came and informed Mr Rush of the object of his Mission, and he told him that nothing in the Law prevented the building and sending away the vessels as a commercial speculation— They had been built accordingly, and were now ready for Sea, with their Crews on board, lying at New-York at an expence of a thousand dollars a day— But the Spanish Consuls and Agents had seduced away some of his Officers and a part of his Crew. It was upon the Affidavits of some of his own Officers that he and his Captains had been arrested by warrants from judge Livingston. He had also been obliged to make an ostensible transfer of his two Ships to his Captains Delano and Skinner, and to have them registered in their names. And now the Ships were attached to answer for the debts of those Captains. He found it therefore impracticable to execute the orders of his Government— His funds were exhausted, and his only resource now was to sell his vessels, just as they are. But they are built for vessels of War, and are not saleable for purposes of Commerce— He came therefore now to enquire if the Government of the United States would purchase them— I promised to lay the proposal before the President, and give him a verbal answer, as soon as I shall receive it. I asked him what price he would ask for the vessels. He said he could not now exactly tell; but if the President thought the officer admissable he would immediately ascertain. I desired him to present his proposal in writing, and he said he would bring it at two O’Clock on Monday. It was near six when I came home, and the Evening was cool enough to admit of reading by Candle light, which I did.

9. VI:Cardelli was here great part of the day. He had finished the bust, but we found that he had totally failed in the likeness; so he asked for another sitting which I gave him; he altered it very much but will ultimately not get a likeness. We had a long visit from Mr and Madame de Neuville. He returned last Evening from his tour to Bristol, and New-York. He said he had a packet for me from Mr Onis—a Reply, upon the Affair of Pensacola— That Onis was extremely anxious to preserve Peace, and so were the Spanish Government; but that they could not agree to the boundaries proposed by us west of the Mississippi. And he was very desirous of knowing our ultimatum on the subject. I told him Mr Onis’s, anxieties for Peace were very laudable, but I supposed he was governed by his Instructions— That as to the
desire of the Spanish Government for Peace, it was just like the Harlequin Roi, in the French Play. Harlequin is made to fancy himself a King; and whoever comes to take his commands, he always answers je veux le bien—or as much as to say, “let right be done”— Just so the Spanish Government says, Let there be Peace; but will agree to nothing which is necessary to secure Peace. De Neuville promised to call upon me to-morrow and deliver the despatch from Mr Onis— I walked an hour before dinner to the river. Mrs Adams spent the Evening at Mr de Neuville’s. I was at home.

10. VI: I received yesterday a Letter from Mr R. King relating to the Construction of the Navigation Act of the last Session of Congress, and called this Morning on the Comptroller of the Treasury Mr Anderson, and had some conversation with him concerning it. I afterwards consulted Mr Calhoun upon it; we all concur in opinion with Mr King; but I concluded to send his Letter to the President, and take his directions. Mr Hyde de Neuville brought me the packet from Mr Onis— He borrowed of me yesterday, de Vergennes’s Memoir upon Louisiana, and I read to him the part of Louis 14th.s grant to Crozat, describing the boundary. This day he took minutes of the English Atlas, published in 1721. which we have in the Office, and of De Lisle’s map, republished in 1782, both of which mark the Rio Bravo as the Western boundary of Louisiana— He said he would state them particularly in his despatches to the Duke de Richelieu— Mr Aguirre came also and gave me his written proposals that the Government of the United States should purchase his ships. Mr Calhoun called, making preparation to send his orders to the Officer commanding at Pensacola, to the Spaniards— He wished previously to see Onis’s Letter, and will wait for the translation of it to be made— Mr Pettibone was at the Office, about his Chimnies— Mrs Adams spent the Evening abroad— Mr Bailey was part of it here— Anxious to obtain his furlough.

11. VI: Called this morning at the Metropolis Bank; the meeting of the Directors is to be to-morrow. Mr Calhoun was at my Office, but the translation of Onis’s Letter was not completed. I received a Note from Mr Bagot, relating to the Execution of our Act of Congress, concerning Navigation; which he apprehends may interfere with the Commercial Convention of July 1815. He had already spoken to me on the subject— Mrs Adams was quite unwell this Evening.

12. V: I was again at the Comptroller of the Treasury, Anderson’s Office, to converse with him on the subject of Mr Bagot’s Note. Anderson says, that the decision of the questions on the Navigation should have been a Cabinet determination— Though he had always been averse to any such thing as a Cabinet— But the instructions to the Collectors, must go from the Secretary of the Treasury, and as he is absent, they must be prepared by me; or at least, he the Comptroller must have them ready prepared for him, before he issues them— I called at Mr Wirt, the Attorney General’s Office, but he has not returned from Baltimore— I left with Mr Calhoun the translation of Onis’s Letter, which is at length finished— There were several thunder showers this day and Evening— Mr ten Cate was here, and we had Music.

13. IV: Rising before day-break I saw Orion rise in front of my chamber door which opens upon a porch. I likewise saw Sirius which rose about four. I had entertained the opinion that this Star was not visible during the dog-days, but from his brightness this morning, I suspect he might be seen by good eyes even after Sunrise— I bathed in the Potowmack at five; ten Cate had promised to meet me there. He arrived after I had come out of the water, and I went in again with him— I called at the Metropolis Bank, and arranged there the business for the payment of the second instalment on the Shares in the Planter’s Bank of Prince George’s— Renewed also my Note payable the 25th. instant—for sixty days longer. Mr Calhoun called at my Office and communicated to me the substance of his orders to the Officer at Pensacola. I despatched the Instructions to A. H. Everett, and wrote to the President. Heat oppressive.

14. V: I was up several times in the Night, and Star-gazing, my chamber door being open— Orion rose, in his grandeur before me, but a morning Cloud intercepted the dog-star from my view— I bathed in the river alone. Mr Bagot came to the Office to ask again if the proceedings of the Court Martial who sentenced the two Englishmen to be executed, had been received— I told him they had not— He said the Newspapers were publishing accounts of it, and he should soon have reason to believe they were in every body’s hands but his— I told him they were not in ours— That Captain GadsdenGeneral Jackson’s Aid de Camp, was daily
and hourly expected. General Jackson had stated that he should send by him the papers and documents which he would not trust to the conveyance of the Mail— There is an Editorial Article in a Georgia Newspaper, mentioning that the Editor had seen the trial, and speaking of the Letters of Arbuthnot to Mr Bagot as furnishing full proofs against the writer— I had not seen any thing else, but Bagot says that he has seen in New-York Newspapers more particular statements— He appeared to be a good deal excited. I again promised to give him suitable notice as soon as the documents shall be received— I spoke to him of his note relating to the Bonds and securities, to be required under the Navigation Act of last Session of Congress, in the case of British vessels loading Articles of exportation from the United States; and told him we should endeavour to discriminate between Articles suited exclusively for the European Markets and dispense with the Bonds for them— I also told him that the Act of Parliament and order in Council, opening the Ports of Halifax and St. John’s, would have no effect upon the operation of our Navigation act, and that British vessels from those Ports would not be admitted into the United States— Mr Calhoun also called upon me to ask my opinion concerning certain particulars of the Orders to be given to the commanding Officer at Pensacola for the surrender— He concluded however to refer them to further orders hereafter— Mrs Adams spent the Evening at Mrs Middleton’s in Georgetown.

15. IV: Bathed in the Potowmack alone. Colonel Bomford was at the Office concerning the settlement of the late Mr Barlow’s Accounts. I received a number of Packages, and among the rest James’s Naval and Military History of the late War between the United States and Great Britain. Looking into these Volumes I became so much engaged with them that they absorbed all the Office hours. They are written with considerable ability, and with extreme and anxious labour to exalt the naval and military character of Great Britain, by the Events of the late War, and to depress that of the American People. It is an unceasing argument upon every event, with all the rancour of War in the heart of the author, against the United States. It will accordingly be a very popular work in England, while it will keep alive the irritable national feeling in this Country. There is no doubt among us, much vain boasting about the late War; and there is as much of it in England, but aggravated and made more ridiculous by the soreness of feeling at the disasters which they actually suffered by Sea and Land. I rode to and from my Office. In the Evening we went to the Theatre and saw the Honeymoon and the Poor Soldier, tolerably well performed. The heat was very distressing. Mr and Madame Hyde de Neuville, Mr Roth and Mr Thierry were there— A Carpenter at work on a house now building, for Franzoni, next door to ours, fell from the scaffolding and was severely hurt, this afternoon.

16. IV:30. Saw Sirius till within ten minutes of Sunrise— He rose this morning as near to four O’Clock, as I could ascertain it. Orion had vanished entirely before the dawn. I bathed with Antoine in the Potowmack, it was the day of the full moon, and a high tide. Cardelli came, and cast the hollow mould, the creaux perdu of the bust. I had never seen and had no idea of the manner of casting Statues in Plaster— There is nothing in the work that can properly be called Sculpture. The first mould is taken in soft red clay worked by the hand—the second is this Plaister shell moulded over it in two halves— The Bust itself is cast in this, and must be done hereafter. Cardelli dined with us— I wrote to A. H. Everett. Mrs Adams spent the Evening at her Sister Boyd’s.

17. IV:30. Suspended probably for the remainder of this year, the morning baths in Potowmack river. I called upon Mr Nourse, the Register of the Treasury, and left with him United States Stocks 6 and 7 per Cents to be transferred to the Books at Philadelphia. Mr John Graham came to my Office, and asked for a decision as to the additional allowance of Compensation to him and Mr Rodney, for their Mission to South-America. It was a few days more than a year from their first appointment to their return to the United States. He expected therefore that they should be allowed a usual year’s Salary of public
Ministers—that is 3000 dollars in addition to the 6000 which they have received— With this he said they would be satisfied; and to this they thought themselves entitled— Mr Rodney particularly who had been a member of Congress, and Attorney General considered it rather as a point of honour than merely in a pecuniary point of view. I promised to lay the statement of this claim before the President and accordingly wrote to him to that effect— Mr Calhoun sent me a Letter from Captain Gadsden, General Jackson’s Aid de Camp, written by his direction, and stating that on the 5th. of May he had despatched to the Secretary at War from Forta detailed Report of all his proceedings till that time; and a Copy of the proceedings of the Court Martial on Arbuthnot and Ambrister, and the original Letters upon which they were condemned— These despatches have never been received. He promises to send duplicates in a few days. I called upon Calhoun, to enquire if he knew any thing further of this very extraordinary circumstance, the miscarriage of those most important despatches; but he did not— Mrs Adams was again at her sister Boyd’s this Evening— Boyd has resigned his Office as a Clerk in the War Department, and is offered an appointment as Indian Agent at Mackinaw. This Morning was cool; and a rainy Night began soon after Sunset.

18. IV:30. The rain continued all Night, and part of this Morning. I made some preparations for the arrangement of papers, before setting out upon our Eastern tour, which absorbed so much of my time that I had none left for attention to the Report on Weights and Measures— Called at the Branch and Metropolis Banks— At the Office called upon Mr Calhoun for information about Hassler’s Salary, and on Mr Homans at the Navy Department, about a drawing of the Flag of the United States for the French Minister. I sent at last for the Volumes, containing the Secret Journals of the Old Continental Congress, and their foreign Correspondence, which by a Resolution of the last Session of Congress are to be published. The appointment of a person to superintend the compilation has been postponed, until I have been obliged to undertake it myself— It was again past five when I came home.

19. V: Wrote a private Letter to R. Rush, and upon reaching the Office, found a despatch from him N. 24. and packets of English Newspapers, some of which I unfortunately took up, and they absorbed my time till five O’Clock— I received a Letter from the President opening occupation to me, to which I am at present unable to attend. Joshua Boyd dined with us. I spent the Evening at Mr Calhoun’s— Mrs Calhoun’sbrother was there.

20. V: Mr.Adams came this morning to my house; he was one of our acquaintance in Russia, in the year 1810. He says he served in the army through the whole of the late War, and was among the disbanded at the end of it. He now comes to solicit an office in some of the departments. Mr Anderson the Comptroller came with Mrs Anderson, and paid us a visit. At the Office there came Mr Mitchell, late Consul at St. Pierre’s Martinique and said he had been making application to Mr Calhoun; who told him that General Gibson would soon be here, as Commissary General and would have to appoint several Clerks— That he Calhoun should leave the nomination of them to Gibson himself, and Mitchell must come to me, and get a Letter recommending him to Gibson— I gave him accordingly such a Letter— Looking over the Volumes of secret Journals of the old Congress, to be copied for publication, I was engaged till past five and it was near six when I reach home— Immediately after dinner, to my great surprize, General Peter B. Porter came in, just from New-York— He enquired when I should have a leisure hour to talk with him, and I named to-morrow at ten O’Clock at my house— The hot weather has returned again, very oppressive.

21. IV:30. Partly drafted a Letter to Mr Aguirre, by direction of the President. General Porter came to my house and afterwards to the Office, and explained his motives for coming here at this time. It is the old grudge between him and Hawkins, the Agent to the Commission which brought him here. He says that Hawkins moves about in his agency with his wife, and a family of Servants, cooks and chambermaids, enormously expensive, and charging all to the public. That he is so overwhelmed with debt that he is held to bail upon a suit in Canada, and now dares not cross the line, from thence, for fear of other writs out against him in the State of New-York. That there is no security for any public money that might be entrusted to him.
He says also that Hawkins has been breeding strife between him the Commissioner, and Adams, the Astronomer to the Commission, and that all the stir made in Congress last Winter against him was raised by Hawkins, intriguing with Mr Spencer, a member of Congress from New-York, and Son of Ambrose Spencer— Porter expressed some apprehension that I had been personally unfriendly to him—and countenanced the charges against him last Winter— I assured him that his suspicion was entirely without foundation— He complained that the charges for his private expences were not allowed in addition to his Salary, while those of the Agent, whose Salary he said had been increased to equal that of the Commissioner, were allowed. He further insisted that the private expences of the Commissioners under the Treaty of 1794. had been allowed; and that the Salaries of the American Commissioners under that Treaty had been the same as those of the British Commissioners, and that it was £1200 Sterling each— I told him that I had settled the agreement with Lord Grenville upon this subject myself, but he still persisted that Coll. Barclay had told him it was otherwise—that he had received £1200 though he had not crossed the Sea to execute the Commission, and Mr Bagot had told him £1200 was the standing Salary of all British Commissioners for all sorts of Services— I told him that this could not apply to cases whether there was a compact upon the subject with another Government— That the private expences of the Commissioner had not been allowed under the former Commissions, and were not allowed to the Agents now. I added it was my belief that if the Executive should allow these claims now, Congress would at the next Session either refuse the appropriation, or take some other measure which would put an end to the Commissions altogether— And I mentioned to him the Resolution passed by the House of Representatives, the last Evening of the late Session. As to Hawkins, I told him he might dismiss all fear of his having the public money to waste, and I read to him my Letter to Hawkins of 5. May giving him the President’s explicit directions concerning the subordination of the agent’s office to that of the Commissioner, and confining the accountability for the expences of the Commission, to the Commissioner. The General was but partially satisfied with my explanations, and I think it is not in my power to satisfy him. This afternoon there were three Balloons sent up from Gibson’s, the tavern, next door to my house— A mulatto boy fell into Burnside’s Boiler, and was scalded to death— Mr ten Cate was here, and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith— ten Cate hurried back from a tour to Harper’s ferry, on hearing of the arrival at New-York of the Viscount de Quabeck his Successor.

22. IV: I passed the night without closing my eyes, under a perpetual irritation of the skin over my face and almost every part of the body, which I supposed to be the effect of what is called prickly heat— But on changing my linen this morning I discovered it was caused by a nest of Spiders just from the egg-shell, so small that most of them were perceptible only by their motion. It was like the continual titillation of a feather passing over the skin at a thousand places at once— It was a night of exquisite torture without pain— My linen and body were covered with them. I immediately stripped, changed all the clothes I had been wearing, and took a warm bath at Burnside’s. How this horrible creeping Nation got upon me, I could not exactly ascertain— They had already produced a cutaneous inflammation, and almost an eruption in various places— I rode to and from my Office, and called on the Attorney General Mr Wirt, to consult him upon the Construction of the Navigation Act of last Session, and some other points. He told me that he had received a Letter from my father, with a copy of Dr Mayhew’s Sermon, upon the martyrdom of Charles I. Wirt said my father was plucking every feather from the plumage of his Hero, Patrick Henry— Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us.

23. V: Though not entirely relieved from my host of Spiders, and although still suffering severely from the inflammation they had raised upon me, I had a night of sound Sleep, and this Morning took a cooler in a portion of Glauber Salts. Cardelli came and cast the bust, and afterwards dined with us. Mr Bailey was
also this morning at the Office, and I sent him a Letter to be despatched for the President. Mr and Madame Hyde de Neuville paid us visits, and I had a further long conversation with him upon our affairs with Spain— His avowed Instructions are to do every thing in his power to preserve Peace, between the United States and Spain; and his secret Instructions are to support the cause of Spain to the utmost of his power—. He returned the Memoir of Count de Vergennes upon Louisiana, which he had some time since borrowed of me— After they went away, I received a note from him, mentioning that he had just got a Letter from Mr Onis, and would be glad to see me this Evening at his house or mine— Mrs Adams went there in the Evening, and I called there for her— There was company, and de Neuville told me he would call at my Office, to-morrow at two O’Clock— Mr and Mrs Frye, with Thomas Hellen, and Robert Buchanan, came in after dinner. As is now too usual with me, the Sunday was the busiest day in the week. I wrote to the President but ran in arrear with this Journal.

24. IV:30. Had a second sleepless Night, from a remainder of the same cause which produced the former. Mr Stoughton, who is attached to the Spanish Legation, and has just arrived here from Bristol, Pennsylvania called yesterday to ask of me from Mr Onis an answer to his last Letter, which I promised to send him before I leave the City. I called at the Office of the Comptroller, Mr Anderson, and left with him the draft of Instructions to the Collectors of the Customs, upon the new Navigation Act— I also called at the Attorney General’s Office, to consult with him upon the question proposed by the President, whether a proclamation should not issue, offering a reward for the apprehension of Captain Obed Wright. Mr Wirt was gone to Port Tobacco for the week— The french Minister Hyde de Neuville, came to tell me the substance of the Letter he had received from Mr Onis. It was to say that he should not come to Washington till October, and that he was yet waiting for Instructions. De Neuville still urged concession on the part of the United States on the question of boundary west of the Mississippi— I told him it was out of the question. He then enquired what I should answer on a claim that France has set up to special privileges in the Ports of Louisiana— It is a captious and groundless pretension, raised for the purpose of a pretext to put off the adjustment of our claims— I told him that as my answer would in substance only repeat what I had already told him in answer to a former Note on the same Subject I had been reluctant at sending it to him, and had therefore not yet prepared it. He appeared to be much irritated at this and with apparent difficulty suppressed his feelings. Mr Calhoun came to tell me that he had another Letter from General Jackson; who has copies of all the Letters which miscarried by the Mail.

25. IV:30. Employed all the morning, in writing to the President. Called at the Metropolis Bank, and renewed my Note there. The President of the Bank J. P. van Ness was there, and I ascertained their mode of calculating interest upon their Notes. they consider 60 days as one sixth of a year, and then add four days for the grace instead of three—so they take one per cent for sixty days, and 1/15 of that sum, for the grace— I told them I thought this was not conformable to law; but they said it was the invariable practice of all the Banks. I was at Mr Calhoun’s Office, and read him a draft of a reply to Mr Onis, on his last Note concerning the capture of Pensacola; he advised some alterations which were accordingly made— This being St: Louis’s day, Mr Hyde de Neuville had a large evening party, Ball and Supper at his house, which we attended.

26. V:30.Judge Thruston called upon me this morning, to apply for the Office of Consul at Tunis, for his Son, a young man of one or two and twenty, now a Clerk in my Office, Appointed at the solicitation of the same judge, who says that his son has a violent passion to go abroad—though he himself does not encourage or countenance him in it— He said it was true that he was very young; but not much younger than Mr Anderson now Consul at Tunis, and who has returned to this Country— I assured the judge of my own friendly dispositions both towards him and his son; but told him, first that Mr Anderson had not resigned his office as Consul at Tunis. Secondly that the example of his youth, and the inconveniences which had perhaps arisen from it would operate rather against another similar appointment than in favour of it. Thirdly, that the appointment itself with the Salary now annexed to it was so far from being desirable, that if Mr Anderson should resign it would only be because he could not live there, as was the case with all
our Consuls in Barbary, excepting only the Consul General at Algiers— The judge professed to be satisfied— General P. B. Porter came to the Office for a draft of money, and Mr ten Cate to take leave. He had on Monday delivered his Letter of recall. I gave him to read the Letter of Recredence, to the Baron de Nagell, the Dutch Minister of foreign Affairs, which I had prepared for him— He afterwards sent to request a copy of it, which I directed should be furnished him— Mrs Adams, with Mary-Hellen, and our German boy, Philip left the City to go as far as Ross’s tavern, eleven Miles, this Evening, and to proceed to-morrow to Baltimore; where I am to join them the next day in the Stage— They went in our own Carriage at four O’Clock in the afternoon. Cardelli came this Evening to take leave, on our departure.

27. V: I was engaged all the morning in preparation for my journey, and in drafting a Letter to our Minister at Rio de Janeiro T. Sumter junr. to be sent by the Macedonian frigate, which is to be despatched immediately to the Pacific Ocean. I am obliged to leave still a great number of Letters, some of them important unanswered— It is with great reluctance that I leave my Post for this short visit to my relations and friends— Other motives, I should set aside; but the age of my father and mother is an admonition to improve the time of passing a few days with them, while the candles burn. A partial release from the oppressive cares of my station is indeed an indulgence; but which I ought perhaps not to allow myself. After the experience of a year the duties of the Office are as severe, and my anxieties connected with them as great as they were in anticipation— The Events of the year have been of no strongly marked character—No public misfortune, and no good success. The administration has been assailed in various ways both in the House of Representatives in Congress, and in public newspapers— Assailed both insidiously and openly; and the attack in regard to its object has been concentrated exclusively upon me. The defence has been absolutely nothing. The faithful execution of my duties, to the utmost of my power, is the only answer I can give to censure— I was a short time at the Office, where Mr J. P. Van Ness called upon me for papers which he had some time since put into the hands of the President, and which are now not to be found. W. S. Smith passed an hour with me this Evening.

28. IV:30. At Six, the Stage for Baltimore called for me at my house— I had as fellow passengers Mrs Grayson of Kentucky, a young widow, daughter of the late John Breckenridge, with whom I sat some time in the Senate of the United States, and who was afterwards Attorney General. She was accompanied by her brother, who has just finished his studies at Princeton College, and is now going there to take his degree, at the approaching Commencement— A Coll: Cabell of Virginia, General P. B. Porter, and Coll. Lane the Commissioner of the Public Buildings. We breakfasted at Ross’s tavern, eleven Miles from Washington, and reached Gadsby’s tavern at Baltimore, at 2 O’Clock P.M. I there found Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen, who had arrived last Evening, by an easy journey with our own Carriage and horses— My wife had engaged us all to dine with Mr Hoffmann, a young lawyer, married to a relation of Susan Buchanan’s, and with whom she resides. We also found there a Mr and Mrs Coles— He is also a lawyer and as he told me an old acquaintance of my brother’s. At five O’Clock, immediately after dinner we went on board the Steam-boat Philadelphia, Captain Trippe, and proceeded up the Bay to Frenchtown— General Porter, and Mrs Grayson with her party, were still our companions, and we had now many others, among whom were the Marquis de Fougères, appointed Consul of France at Charleston, South-Carolina, and Mr Calhoun a merchant of Baltimore, an acquaintance of the years 1795. 6. 7. then very intimate with my brother. He is now concerned in a manufacturing establishment, at Baltimore, and is going to Rhode-Island and Massachusetts to see and examine the management of similar undertakings there. He is travelling with an associate, a Mr Price, whom he introduced to me— About 1/2 past one in the Morning we reached Frenchtown.

29. At Frenchtown we found Stages ready to receive us, and started just before two in the Morning. at five we came to Newcastle, the distance being sixteen Miles, and there immediately entered the Steam-Boat, Delaware, Captain Wheldon, in which we came to Philadelphia; we landed at the wharf at nine in the Morning, about five minutes before the boat of the rival line; the boats of which go from Baltimore to Elkton; and from Wilmington to Philadelphia. They start at the same time, and the boat on the Chesapeake Bay, of the other line being new, and with a more powerful engine than ours gained two or three miles upon us on the passage up the Bay; which we regained however by the superior swiftness of our boat on the Delaware— We came immediately to lodge at Renshaw’s Mansion house Hotel; where we found Mr William Lee the Auditor, returning to Washington after a long visit, to New-York— Half an hour afterwards came in Mr Leichleitner, who introduced to me the Viscount de Quabeck; and this Gentleman delivered to me a credential Letter from the Baron de Nagell, the Dutch Minister of foreign Affairs; announcing him as Charge d’Affaires from the Netherlands to reside here. He proposes to go on to Washington, immediately. In the course of the day, I called on S. Ewing, whom I found recovering from a severe bilious illness, and from a confinement of several weeks—and I also called at the house of J. Connell, but did not find him at home. Mr John Vaughan, Mr Comack; and Connell paid us visits—and J. Sergeant and his brother— Mrs Adams was much overcome by the fatigue of the journey, and the total loss of repose last Night. She had some fever this Evening, and retired very early to bed— I was not much better myself; and totally disqualified either for writing or reading.

30. V: After a good Night’s rest I found myself much refreshed; and this morning able to write very slowly, that is, as well as I ever shall— Connell came at ten O’Clock, and I went with him to the Presbyterian Meeting house in Market-Street, where the public worship was performed by Dr Wilson, the Minister of the Church. We sat in Mr Connelly’s pew. Coming out of the Church I met a Mr Emery formerly of Boston, who told me he had not seen me these twenty years— Mr and Mrs Connell came with me to visit Mrs Adams, but she continued so unwell that she was obliged to confine herself, almost the whole day to her bed, and she could not see them— Mr Petry the French Consul had paid us a visit yesterday, and left Cards. I now returned it, and found him at home. I also called at the lodgings of the Viscount de Quabeck; but he had gone off this Morning to Washington. Mr Buck the Consul from Hamburg; had also called upon me yesterday, but I could not find his house to return his visit— I received a packet of despatches from the Department of State; with Letters from Mr Rush, and one enclosed, for his Mother. I dined at S. Ewing’s. Mrs Adams was so unwell that she could not go. Mr John Sergeant was the only other person of the party, with Mr and Mrs Ewing. In the Evening, I called at Mrs Rush’s, and gave her the Letter from her Son, which I had received. Her daughter Mrs Cuthbert was with her, having arrived lately from England. Returning to my lodgings, Mr Vaughan came and passed the remainder of the Evening with me.

31. V: At six this Morning Mr Vaughan called upon us again and accompanied us to the Market Street wharf, where we went into the Steam-Boat AEtna, Captain Kellum, in which we came up the river Delaware twenty miles to Bristol. The tide was against us, and it was almost ten when we arrived. The Post-Chaise was standing on the wharf, ready to receive us, but in changing our baggage from the Boat to the Carriage, my Umbrella was left in the Boat; and before I could send for it, the boat had left the wharf, proceeding to Bordentown. This transfer of baggage between the Steam-Boats and Carriages, is among the great inconveniences of this mode of traveling— It is always a scene of great confusion, and some accident scarcely ever fails of happening, with loss to somebody. In that boat, I met Mr Sansom, a Quaker traveller and publisher, and Mr Hall, a young man, who was among the applicants for the appointment of Secretary to Mr Campbell’s mission in Russia— Our companions in the Post-Chaise (which is merely a Stage Coach upon Springs) were a Dr and Mrs Maris of Baltimore, with her sister; entire Strangers to us, but with whom we became in the course of the day, much acquainted. At Princeton we wished to have seen Johnson Hellen who is a student there, but could not stop long enough— We dined at Brunswick, and at Woodbridge crossed in a horse-boat to Staten-Island.
We crossed Staten-Island, about eight miles, upon a Turnpike made by Vice-President Tompkins, and connected with his Steam-Boat Nautilus, in which we proceeded seven miles to New-York. The Vice-President resides upon the Island, the greater part of which he owns, and has built the Steam-Boat and made the Turnpike, as a speculation to divert the course of traveling between New-York and Philadelphia— It was an adventurous enterprize, and so expensive that it very nearly overwhelmed and ruined him; but has at last completely succeeded and now yields him an affluent income. We landed at New-York between seven and eight O’Clock, and took lodgings at the City Hotel, Broadway, together with our companions of the Post-Chaise. Mr M’Cormick soon afterwards called and paid us a visit; and engaged us to dine with him to-morrow.
Day. Like the preceding Month till I left Washington— Now travelling.
